utterances: Of course, the president knows that Congress will also want to have its own investigation and that, in fact, Senators Susan Collins and Joe Lieberman--that's the Republican from Maine, Susan Collins, and the Democrat from Connecticut in Lieberman--have already begun the mechanics for having their own investigation.
They are the chairman and ranking member respectively of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, and they have the jurisdiction to investigate this.
They are also two people who were largely responsible for setting up the Department of Homeland Security.

And since FEMA is now part of the Department of Homeland Security, this is their baby, in a way, and they are quite interested in how poorly all this has gone and they obviously want to dismantle it and get inside it and find out what happened.
Ron, remind us of some of the issues that have fallen by the wayside now.
And do you expect them to eventually creep back on to the agenda but in a different form or will the fight be the same?
And I just want you to understand that this is not over.
I think, really, it's just getting deeper and deeper.
I feel great about what I do.
I think I'm a blessed individual.
I mean, you know, look at me, and I also realize that because I'm given this opportunity, I'm--there's a lot to be expected of me to provide for the people that I take care of.
And I know I can do something about this.
And trust me, these past several months, I actually thought, well, you know, the hell with it, but I just can't let it go.
(Soundbite of train whistle)

In the long run, of course, such issues as the estate tax or Social Security changes the president wants or immigration changes that the Republican Party would like to push--all of these things have been interrupted and postponed, but they'll come back eventually.
We just don't know exactly when.
In some form, I suspect, Congress will talk about extending the elimination of the estate tax.

Maybe it will not be totally eliminated, as Congressman Foley suggested, but something is going to be done on that front before we reach the expiration point for the elimination that was passed back in 2001.
Some form of estate tax is probably going to survive.
Also, the Social Security changes--in some sense, those are going to emerge from committee in the House, from the Ways and Means Committee.
It'll be called something like retirement security.
It will not be called Social Security reform so much; it'll be called retirement security.
We'll see that before the end of the year.

All these issues will come back, but what I don't expect is the big push towards enactment that the the administration and the Republican leaders in Congress had hoped for in September and October because of this enormous--I won't call it a distraction; I'll call it a shift in focus for the entire government.
And this is going to very, very costly.
There's a wire report here that President Bush intends to seek $40 billion as the next installment for hurricane relief.
That's got to change the way people are looking at these other economic issues on the Hill.
And that's on to of the 10 billion that emergency approval was gained for by Congress last Friday.
I've seen the figure 100 billion, I've seen the figure 150 billion.
That, for example, would represent a 50-percent increase in the national deficit unless some other revenue were going to be produced to make up the cost.
All right.
Thanks so much for being with us today, Ron.
My pleasure, Lynn.
Ron Elving is NPR's senior Washington editor, and he joined me in Studio 3A.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary.
Now, you know we couldn't come to Austin without trying the barbecue.
And one name kept popping up - Franklin Barbecue.
You even heard the mayor shout it out.
It's a barbecue spot on the east side of Austin famous for its brisket and its long lines.
We got there at around 7:30 in the morning, almost four hours before Franklin opens, and let's just say we were not alone.
So we got here at 1 a.m. We were at the bars there.
I'm from Austin.
They're new to town.
They wanted to come to Franklin's because it's a thing.
So we went and waited and slept on lawn chairs for the last five hours.
Ben White and his buddies were half awake, but they were first in line because yes, you heard him right.
He got there at 1 in the morning.
Now, that's a little extreme.

But if you want to make sure you get some meat, the experts we spoke to said the ideal time to get in line is around 6 a.m. By the time we got there, dozens of brisket aficionados were in a line that went all the way to the corner and wrapped around the building.
Some people were sleeping.
Some were drinking the usual morning beverages and some other things.
And everybody was trying to stay occupied.
We got Settlers of Catan.
We're going to double dutch.
We're going to double dutch.
We brought a football, some cards and each other's lovely company.
That was Andrew Clem.
He's local.
But the guy next to him, he wasn't.
My name is Guillermi (ph).
I'm from Brazil.
I am here just for the barbecue, yeah.
I'm doing a barbecue trip around Texas.
Mincho Jacobs helped his friend Aaron Franklin and Aaron's wife Stacey start Franklin Barbecue seven years ago.
The guys had moved to Austin to play music, Mincho on the bass and Aaron on the guitar.
But that didn't pan out, so they turned to the Q.
Now the place is world famous.
Now, you know that after all that hype we had to taste this barbecue for ourselves.
But first, Mincho showed us how the sausage and the rest of the food is made.
All right, so you're going to smell smoky after this.
OK.
But, you know, that's not a bad thing.
Oh, wow.
Luckily, you're coming when it's not too hot.
This the man (unintelligible).
Yes.
Because normally in this smokehouse it'd be, like, 120 degrees.
This is where the magic happens.
Or lot of sweating (laughter).
The room was holding six SUV-sized woodburning smokers.
And like the food, the smokers are homemade.
We built them, yeah, back when we were learning how to barbecue.
When Aaron Franklin started talking about doing barbecue, he also learned how to weld.
And now we welded all these.
He did a lot of the welding in our backyard.
It's really crazy, but it's very DIY.
Mincho says that's the essence of this whole operation, DIY and some elbow grease.
We're cooking food for tomorrow right now.
It is 1:44 p.m. We're cooking food that's not going to be eaten until 10 a.m. tomorrow morning.
And it's going to come off at 2, 3 in the morning, we're going to be putting on briskets.
So it's - it takes a long time, a lot of labor.
We're doing chemistry.
It is really backwoods cooking.

You're burning - what we use is post oak, which is really traditional here, but it has a certain chemical composition of nitrogen and carbon and acids that you're trying to burn to release to make this meat sing.
Since we're here on business covering South by Southwest, I had to ask Mincho about the convention that's taken over the city.
Well, like most Austin nights it's a mixed blessing.
It's big and it's crazy and it's made the city kind of crazy.
But, you know, that's Austin nowadays.
Some people think we're too big, too.
We make 2,300 pounds of meat a day.
It's nuts (laughter).
Welcome to Texas.
Widespread flooding in France, Germany, and Belgium has forced the evacuation of thousands from their homes.
Nearly a dozen people have died.
Highways have turned into waterways.
And in Paris, the Seine River has overflowed its banks, forcing world-famous museums to close.
NPR's Eleanor Beardsley reports.
I'm here in the Fox Beach neighborhood, a few hundred feet from the Atlantic Ocean - or rather, the former Fox Beach neighborhood.
This used to be a working-class area, roughly 180 homes, mostly small bungalows, far away from the hustle and bustle of Manhattan.
But for the past year, the state has been tearing down these homes.
The latest to go, as you can hear behind me, is number 16 Kissam Avenue.
Bill Bye used to live there.
It's a strong roof - was a strong roof, I should say.
After Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, Bye and other homeowners decided their neighborhood was dangerous and increasingly expensive.
The insurance would be too high, property tax, everything would be too high.
The backhoe nibbles away at the house, bit by bit, using its shovel to first knock the roof boards loose, pluck away the gutter, nudge the brick chimney.
Within an hour, the whole thing comes down.
The woman, who lives next door, Franca Costa, is staying, at least for now.
I don't know if they're offering me enough money where I can buy something else for us.
I mean, the guy down there moved into a studio.
I don't want to do something like that once I've owned a house.
Costa is one of only a few holdouts left.
It's not just because of Sandy.
This is wetlands.
It floods in heavy rains and is barely above sea level.
In hot weather, wildfires break out.
If you look at what we're in the midst of right here, you realize houses don't belong here.
That's Joe Tirone.
I talked to him a little ways down the street, where workers are removing the cement slab of another house.
He organized the neighbors and convinced New York state to buyout whoever wanted to sell.
It's insane to think that this looked like this 30 or 40 years ago and someone said oh, I can build some homes here.
The governor of New York, Andrew Cuomo, embraced the buyouts.
He's devoted $600 million of federal Sandy relief money to the project.
That'll cover roughly 750 homes - not just here in Fox Beach, but at other sites on Staten Island and on Long Island as well.
Environmentalists say the money is well worth it.
NRDC, how may I direct your call?
To ask why, I went to the headquarters of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
It's in Manhattan, about 15 miles from Fox Beach.
Eric Goldstein is a senior attorney.
